The U.S. government directly funds the Federal Air Marshal Service (FAMS), not the airlines, through a dedicated budget for inflight security. The 2025 budget for the FAMS is approximately $843 million, covering operations and personnel costs, not a direct subsidy to airlines. This funding is separate from airline expenses, although airlines do incur their own security costs. U.S. taxpayers have provided significant financial support to airlines, most notably through over $50 billion in pandemic-related grants and loans through the Payroll Support Program (PSP), with the
Treasury Department awarding about $59 billion in financial assistance. Beyond pandemic aid, U.S. taxpayers fund the airline industry through infrastructure like airports via the Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF), which also receives money from excise taxes on flights, and provides funding for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
